Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Planning Grant: I/UCRC for Real-Time Intelligence for Smart Electric Grid Operations (RISE)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Clemson University and Georgia Institute of Technology collaboratively propose to form a new Industry University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) for "Real-Time Intelligence for Smart Electric Grid Operations (RISE). Scalable real-time intelligence to dynamically plan and operate our national electricity infrastructure, end-to-end, with more renewable energy sources effectively in terms of cost, reliability, resiliency, and sustainability is a challenge today. The RISE Center will develop new technologies to benefit society for many years to come. Clemson University and Georgia Institute of Technology will involve initiatives that will broaden representation of underrepresented groups in this field. This award will support a planning meeting for the proposed center.

The primary objectives of the proposed center are the following: to develop new algorithms, architectures and methodologies to realize a new operating system of systems paradigm in collaboration with RISE industry members, academe, and government, and to educate and innovate the new generation of engineers, professionals and educators who understand the interdisciplinary (system of systems) nature of the new electric energy industry, where a talent shortage is projected. The RISE concept brings about the integration of power systems, communication and information systems, computational systems, cyber systems, market designs and policy to address the challenge mentioned above. A unique real-time control center test-bed will be developed for the RISE team and industry members to pilot and perform investigations of new applications for smart electric grid operations. The RISE faculty expertise and several centers and laboratories at Clemson University and Georgia Institute of Technology strategically position the two institutions to develop leading-edge industry relevant research to provide the foundation for intelligent smart electric grid operations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Clemson University and Georgia Institute of Technology collaboratively proposed to form a new Industry University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) for "Real-Time Intelligence for Smart Electric Grid Operations (RISE). The center will address the challenge of having scalable real-time intelligence to dynamically plan and operate our national electricity infrastructure, end-to-end, with more renewable energy sources effectively in terms of cost, reliability, resiliency, and sustainability.

A planning meeting of the RISE Center was held on November 12-13, 2015 in Clemson SC from the funding received from NSF, a one-year planning grant. The meeting was attended by university partners, utilities, utility vendors, consultants, utility regulators, DOE Labs and government agencies. Ten projects and several student posters were presented to the potential industry members in attendance.

The mission of the proposed center, as supported by the potential industry members, will be to develop new algorithms, architectures and methodologies to realize a new operating system of systems paradigm in collaboration with RISE industry members, academe, and government, and to educate and innovate the new generation of engineers, professionals and educators who understand the interdisciplinary (system of systems) nature of the new electric energy industry, where a talent shortage is projected.

The RISE center will address the integration of power systems, communication and information systems, computational systems, cyber systems, market designs and policy to address the challenge mentioned above. A unique real-time control center test-bed will be developed to pilot and perform investigations of new applications for smart electric grid operations.

The RISE Center will develop new technologies to benefit society for many years to come. Clemson University and Georgia Institute of Technology will involve initiatives that will broaden representation of underrepresented groups in this field. This award will support a planning meeting for the proposed center. 

The next step for the RISE team is to gather industry membership committees and prepare a full proposal to NSF for possible center award, which is to be submitted in the NSF January 2017 I/UCRC proposal submission window. An virtual Industry Advisory Board was established during the November 2015 planning meeting for the RISE Center with a Chair to assist the center in preparation of the full proposal to NSF.
